alert.note: Alert for Habersham; Stephens (Georgia) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flood Advisory issued May 08 at 1:40AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 530 AM EDT EARLY THIS MORNING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...A portion of northeast Georgia, including the following counties, Habersham and Stephens. * WHEN...Until 530 AM EDT. * IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 134 AM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated heavy rain due to a series of showers and thunderstorms repeatedly affecting Habersham and Stephens Counties in northeast Georgia. Radar and rain gauge reports indicate that 1 to 2 inches of rain has fallen in this area over the past 3 hours, and an additional inch of rain is likely early this morning before the precipitation ends. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Toccoa, Clarkesville, Cornelia, Baldwin, Demorest, Mount Airy, Alto, Martin, Avalon, Lake Hartwell, Raoul, Boydville, Hollywood and Eastanolee. Flooding is most likely along Hazel Creek, Mud Creek, Nancy Town Creek, and tributaries feeding into the Middle Fork Broad River in Habersham County. Flooding is also likely along Toccoa Creek, Eastanollee Creek and tributaries feeding the Savannah River in Stephens County. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: When it is safe to do so, please report flooding threatening roads or property to the National Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800, 2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, by posting on our Facebook page, or via Twitter using hashtag NWSGSP. Your message should describe the specific location where impacts occurred and the depth of flooding observed. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding.
